title: Epic: City Logo Lab Upgrades (Scale, Schemes, Skyline, Trucks)
description:
Upgrade the `/labs/city-logo` playground into a high-power tuning surface for the Living City wordmark.

## Objective
Make it fast to iterate on:
- Visual scale (voxel/pixel density) + overall sizing (including full-width preview)
- Skyline/building silhouette parameters
- Coordinated color schemes (text/buildings/vehicles) to improve legibility and site-wide design cohesion
- Additional vehicle variety (trucks) while keeping rendering performant

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Lab supports adjusting voxel scale, preview width mode (fixed vs full width), and preview size.
- [ ] Lab supports adjusting skyline parameters (min/max height, segment widths) and these affect render output.
- [ ] Lab supports selecting a color scheme (curated palettes) that affects wordmark + vehicles and improves contrast/legibility.
- [ ] Trucks are implemented as an additional vehicle actor (configurable/toggleable).
- [ ] Rendering remains performant (bounded DOM; batch where appropriate).
- [ ] Playwright visual baselines cover the lab’s key scenes and remain stable.
- [ ] Motion sanity checks exist so we can self-verify animation/layout during development.

- [ ] Local verification completed (CI-equivalent commands + visual checks in logo lab).
- [ ] GitHub Actions CI is green for the pushed commit on main before closing this epic.

## Out of Scope
- Accessibility work
- Documentation
- Legacy logo fallback / old header implementation

## Assumptions
- “Resolution” is implemented as **integer voxel scaling** and optional layout parameters (crisp edges), not arbitrary fractional scaling.
- Color customization is via **predefined schemes** (no free-form color picker in V1).
- Lab controls are shareable via URL query params so scenarios can be reproduced.

## Verification Protocol
- Use Node 20 (CI parity): `PATH=/opt/homebrew/opt/node@20/bin:$PATH`
- Local CI-equivalent: `pnpm lint`, `pnpm lint:knip`, `pnpm lint:cycles`, `pnpm type-check`, `pnpm test`, `pnpm build`, `pnpm bundle:check`
- Visual: `LABS_CITY_LOGO=1 SKIP_DB=1 pnpm build && LABS_CITY_LOGO=1 SKIP_DB=1 pnpm start` then `pnpm test:visual`
- Motion sanity: run a Playwright motion smoke test (frame-to-frame change) against `/labs/city-logo` when simulation is playing.
- CI gate: after push, wait for GitHub Actions to be green (`gh run list -c <sha>`) before closing issues and starting the next one.

title: Epic: Atlas Context Files Atlas (Docs-as-Data)
description:
Build the Atlas "Context Files Atlas": a docs-as-data reference for context/instruction files across Copilot, Copilot CLI, Gemini CLI, Claude Code, Codex CLI, Cursor, and Windsurf.

## Objective
- Provide structured, versioned, evidence-backed facts (claims + citations) about how each platform loads and scopes context files.
- Render those facts into a premium UI (platform pages, compare matrix, changelog, simulator) with copyable examples.
- Keep Atlas up to date via a scheduled crawler → extractor → facts diff → PR workflow.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Atlas data contract: zod-validated facts JSON with claim-level evidence and a stable feature taxonomy.
- [ ] Atlas UI: `/atlas` section with platform detail pages rendering artifacts, files, scoping/precedence, claims + citations, and examples.
- [ ] Compare: matrix built from taxonomy + facts, with claim/evidence drilldowns and crosswalk equivalence.
- [ ] Search: generated index + in-Atlas search + command palette entry.
- [ ] Changelog: generated facts diffs + UI pages for browsing entries.
- [ ] Update pipeline: weekly scheduled GitHub Action opens a PR when facts change; never auto-merges.
- [ ] Security: crawler avoids SSRF, respects allowlists, stores minimal excerpts, and zip downloads are path-safe.

## Assumptions
- Atlas content lives in-repo under `atlas/` (facts/guides/examples/snapshots/changelog) and ships with the app.
- Facts extraction is best-effort and guarded by `expectedPhrases` to detect doc drift.
- Excerpts are short (<= ~200 chars) to avoid reproducing large portions of docs.

## Out of Scope
- Accessibility-specific work (keyboard nav, ARIA audits) beyond existing component behavior.
- Writing developer documentation about Atlas implementation.

title: Epic: Design System V2 + Site Redesign

Complete design review and implementation of a refreshed visual system and component architecture that makes global look-and-feel updates trivial.

## Objective
- Establish V2 design tokens (color, type, spacing, radii, motion) with a clear primitive → semantic mapping.
- Upgrade UI primitives/components to consume tokens consistently.
- Migrate all major site surfaces to V2 components for a cohesive, dense, crisp UI.
- Preserve light/dark parity and performance.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Tokens live in one place and are bridged to Tailwind without hard-coded hex values.
- [ ] UI components expose consistent V2 APIs/variants and are used across surfaces.
- [ ] All primary routes (shell, home, browse, detail, builder, auth, static) render with V2 styling.
- [ ] Unit + visual tests pass with updated snapshots.

## Assumptions
- Tailwind + CSS variables remain the styling foundation.
- No data-model or backend changes; UI-only refactor.
- Accessibility and documentation are explicitly out of scope for this epic.

## Out of Scope
- WCAG/a11y remediation beyond existing behavior.
- New documentation/marketing content.
- Major IA or feature changes unrelated to styling.

title: Epic: UX clarity + simplified onboarding
description:
Simplify and clarify how users should use the site (scan folder → understand instructions → build/export), reduce cognitive load, and remove redundant or legacy UX paths.

## Objective
Deliver a coherent, minimal-friction onboarding flow that highlights the primary value path and de-emphasizes secondary complexity across Home, Library, Workbench, and Atlas.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Primary flow is obvious from the homepage and navigation.
- [ ] Atlas Simulator makes folder scan the default and explains outcomes in plain language.
- [ ] Workbench and Library surfaces provide guided next steps and reduced action clutter.
- [ ] Redundant routes/flags are removed or consolidated without breaking key links.
- [ ] Tests and docs reflect the new flow.

## Out of Scope
- Full rebrand or backend data-model changes.
- New paid features or accounts/permissions work.
- Major new product surfaces unrelated to onboarding.

## Assumptions
- The primary persona arrives with a repo and wants to scan for instruction files.
- We can gate changes behind a feature flag for staged rollout.
- Legacy redirect routes (e.g., /browse, /builder) can be consolidated or deprecated if safe.
- Documentation lives in-repo and can be updated alongside UI changes.

title: Infra: CI green + deploy reliability
description:
DoD:
- CI on main is consistently green (checks, e2e, lighthouse, nightly visual) and failures have clear, actionable output.
- CD deploy workflow reliably builds, pushes, deploys, and smoke-tests production without manual steps.
- PR workflows degrade gracefully when secrets are unavailable (e.g., fork PRs) without silently skipping critical coverage for trusted branches.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] CI workflows are green on `main` (checks/e2e/lighthouse/nightly/atlas-update) and failures are actionable.
- [ ] CD workflow builds, pushes, deploys, and runs smoke checks reliably.
- [ ] Fork PRs do not fail due to missing secrets; job summary calls out skipped steps.

title: CI: Triage failures and keep main green
description:
DoD:
- Identify the current failing GitHub Actions workflows (checks.yml, e2e.yml, cd.yml, scheduled workflows) and fix root causes.
- Add/adjust tests and workflow logging so a recurrence is clearly diagnosable from the CI UI.
- Confirm the full CI suite passes on main (multiple consecutive runs) after the fixes.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Identify and fix current CI failures/flakes across `checks.yml`, `e2e.yml`, `cd.yml`, and scheduled workflows.
- [ ] Add/adjust logging/tests so failures are diagnosable from the GitHub Actions UI.
- [ ] Confirm at least 3 consecutive green runs on `main` after fixes.

title: CI: Make secrets-dependent jobs fork-safe
description:
DoD:
- Update workflows that require secrets (e2e.yml, cd.yml) so fork pull requests do not fail due to missing secrets.
- Keep full coverage for trusted contexts (push to main, pull_request from same repo, workflow_dispatch) while skipping only the minimal secret-requiring steps for forks.
- Add explicit, visible messaging in the job summary when steps are skipped due to missing secrets.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Fork PRs do not fail due to missing secrets; secret-dependent steps are skipped with explicit messaging.
- [ ] Trusted contexts (push to `main`, same-repo PRs, workflow_dispatch) run full coverage with secrets.
- [ ] No critical coverage is silently skipped for `main`.

title: CD: Docker buildx + registry cache for faster deploys
description:
DoD:
- Replace the ad-hoc docker build/push in .github/workflows/cd.yml with docker/build-push-action and BuildKit cache.
- Keep tagging scheme (short SHA) and ensure the built image is what gets deployed to Azure Container Apps.
- Ensure the workflow remains reproducible and does not leak secrets into image layers.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `cd.yml` uses `docker/build-push-action` (BuildKit) with registry/cache enabled.
- [ ] Deployed image tag/revision matches the built image (short SHA) used for Azure Container Apps.
- [ ] Workflow does not leak secrets into build args or image layers.

title: CD: Improve post-deploy smoke checks and failure diagnostics
description:
DoD:
- Expand CD smoke checks to cover at least one JSON API endpoint and the health endpoint (and fail fast on non-2xx).
- On failure, emit actionable diagnostics (current revision, recent logs, container app status) in the workflow output while keeping secrets masked.
- Ensure the smoke checks use timeouts and retries to avoid flaky false negatives.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] CD smoke checks hit the health endpoint and at least one JSON API endpoint with timeouts/retries.
- [ ] On failure, workflow outputs actionable diagnostics (revision/status/log pointers) while keeping secrets masked.
- [ ] Smoke checks are reliable enough to avoid flaky false negatives.

title: CI: Publish test reports and artifacts
description:
DoD:
- Configure Vitest to emit JUnit (and optionally JSON) reports in CI and upload them as artifacts.
- Upload coverage artifacts (lcov, summary) even when tests fail, and surface a short summary in the GitHub Actions job summary.
- Ensure Playwright (e2e and nightly visual) uploads traces/screenshots and the HTML report for failed runs.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Vitest emits JUnit (and optional coverage outputs) and uploads artifacts even when tests fail.
- [ ] Playwright uploads HTML report + traces/screenshots for failed runs.
- [ ] GitHub Actions job summary includes a short test/coverage summary.

title: CI: Standardize Node/pnpm versions and caching
description:
DoD:
- Align Node and pnpm usage across workflows (checks, e2e, atlas-update, lighthouse, nightly) to a small, intentional set of versions.
- Ensure pnpm store caching is enabled consistently via actions/setup-node cache: pnpm or pnpm/action-setup.
- Validate that workflows remain deterministic with frozen lockfile and do not rely on global pnpm state.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] All workflows use consistent Node + pnpm versions.
- [ ] pnpm store caching is enabled in all workflows.
- [ ] Workflows use frozen lockfile and do not rely on global pnpm state.

title: Epic: Living City Wordmark Playground (V1)
description:
Complete implementation of a living, configurable cityscape wordmark (text "MARKDOWNTOWN") with day/night scenes, time-of-day animation, and a local playground for rapid iteration.

## Objective
Build a configurable, living 2D city logo that can be iterated on quickly (time-of-day, activity, events) and ship it as the primary wordmark across the app (no legacy fallback).

## Success Criteria
- [ ] A CityWordmark simulation engine + renderer exists (seeded + configurable).
- [ ] Day + night visuals are supported (with dawn/dusk transitions).
- [ ] Local playground exists to scrub time-of-day and toggle/trigger activity.
- [ ] Logo can react to site actions via an event bridge (V1: a few key actions only).
- [ ] Tests exist for core sim utilities and visual baselines for key scenes.
- [ ] Performance is acceptable for header usage (bounded CPU/DOM; no layout jank).
- [ ] Existing wordmark is replaced everywhere (no fallback).

- [ ] For every merged change: local verification is done and GitHub Actions CI is green before starting the next issue.
## Out of Scope
- Formal documentation and accessibility audit (explicitly deferred per request).
- Full cross-device QA; we rely on CI + visual baselines initially.

## Assumptions
- Product name remains "mark downtown"; the logo text renders as "MARKDOWNTOWN" (no spaces).
- V1 targets SVG-first rendering + Web Animations API / rAF where needed; Canvas/WebGL can be explored later if warranted.
- Animations are deterministic by seed to keep visual baselines stable.


## Verification Protocol
- Use Node 20 (CI parity): `PATH=/opt/homebrew/opt/node@20/bin:$PATH`
- Run local CI-equivalent checks: `pnpm lint`, `pnpm lint:knip`, `pnpm lint:cycles`, `pnpm type-check`, `pnpm test`, `pnpm build`, `pnpm bundle:check`
- Layout/visual regression: start app (`pnpm build` + `pnpm start`) and run `pnpm test:visual` (update darwin + linux snapshots when intentional)
- Animation sanity: capture 2+ frames via Playwright against the logo playground and confirm motion/state changes are visible
- CI gate: after push, wait for GitHub Actions to be green (e.g. `gh run list -c <sha>` and `gh run watch --exit-status <run-id>`) before starting next issue

title: Epic: Atlas simulator repo-folder flow
description:
Complete implementation of the repo-folder upload + instruction simulation flow in Atlas.

## Objective
Ensure users can scan a local repo folder (AGENTS.md / Copilot instructions / etc.), simulate per-tool instruction loading, and get actionable insights from the results.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Users can discover the Simulator from Atlas/home navigation and understand what it does.
- [ ] Folder scanning works in supported browsers with clear fallbacks for unsupported ones.
- [ ] Simulation results are accurate, actionable, and explain missing/extra instruction files.
- [ ] End-to-end tests cover manual and folder-based scans.
- [ ] Security/privacy messaging is clear: file contents never leave the browser.

## Out of Scope
- Full redesign of Atlas IA or navigation.
- Server-side repo ingestion or uploads.
- Deep content editing of instruction files.

## Assumptions
- The simulator remains client-only and does not persist repo data server-side.
- We prioritize Chromium browsers first, with a lightweight fallback for others.
- The main value is clarity on which instruction files load per tool, not content analysis.
